turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: Well I, I don't think "living it up" is the right term -- how about "working themselves to death"?

turns.speaker: FORMICA
turns.text: I tell you son, sometimes, at night, I see myself in battle, fighting a horrible, faceless enemy, with the future of our whole species at stake. And always, the dream ends with each of us plunging his sword into the other's heart...

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: Oh, hey, that's great, I think I see an old war buddy over there, it's been fun chatting.  Good luck with the hallucinations.

turns.speaker: FORMICA
turns.text: May I cut in?

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: Oh, of course --

turns.speaker: FORMICA
turns.text: What's this?  A <u>worker</u> has been masquerading as a war hero?!

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: Well it wasn't a masquerade, really, it was more what I'd call a clever ruse --

turns.speaker: FORMICA
turns.text: ARREST HIM!

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: Can't we all settle this like adults -- we're not larvae anymore --

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: General, the severe food shortage that faces the colony...<u>pains</u> me. The thought of any of my children going hungry...  Who's the cutest widdle worker?  You are!  Yes, you!  Don't forget to brush your teeth!  Ship 'er out.  What steps are you taking to remedy the situation?

turns.speaker: FORMICA
turns.text: We are launching a major offensive to expand our foraging territory...

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: Yes, what else?

turns.speaker: FORMICA
turns.text: Please don't worry, your majesty. Leave the worrying to me.  As you know, I'm not an ant of half- measures.  I don't pussyfoot around. This crisis is my number one priority, and I promise you it's being dealt with swiftly, and decisively.

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: No snacking between meals!  Off you go!  Now -- what were we saying?

turns.speaker: FORMICA
turns.text: I do not recollect, your majesty. Will that be all?

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: Yes, General Formica.  Carry on, my good man!  I don't know what we would do without you.

turns.speaker: FORMICA
turns.text: Conversation...yes...well...  Wasn't she briefed?

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: Look, General!  A darling baby soldier!  Don't try to be a hero!  Just make sure you come back in one piece!  Next!

turns.speaker: FORMICA
turns.text: I'll take your suggestion under advisement, Princess.  In the meanwhile --

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: All these parties are so marvellously <u>alike</u>.

turns.speaker: FORMICA
turns.text: They should be...  But there's something funny about that soldier.

turns.speaker: FORMICA
turns.text: Your majesty, I'm afraid matters of state keep me from attending the ceremony.

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: But General -- this tunnel is your baby!  You're sure you can't stay ?

turns.speaker: FORMICA
turns.text: 'Fraid not, your majesty.  Goodbye, your majesty.

turns.speaker: QUEEN
turns.text: Very well, General -- I know you -- all work and no play!

turns.speaker: FORMICA
turns.text: Alright, let's move out!

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: I feel...isolated.  Different.  I've got abandonment issues.  My father flew away when I was just a larva. My mother didn't have much time for me...when you have five million siblings, it's difficult to get attention.  I feel physically inadequate -- I've never been able to lift more than ten times my own weight.  Sometimes I think I'm just not cut out to be a worker.  But I don't have any other options.  I was assigned to trade school when I was just a <u>grub</u>.  The whole system just...makes me feel...<u>insignificant</u>.

turns.speaker: MOTIVATIONAL COUNSELLOR
turns.text: Terrific!  You <u>should</u> feel insignificant!

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: ...I should?

turns.speaker: MOTIVATIONAL COUNSELLOR
turns.text: YES!!!  You know, people ask me, "Doctor, why are you always happy?" And I tell them it's mind over matter.  I don't <u>mind</u> that I don't <u>matter</u>!  Do you get it?  Do you get it?

turns.speaker: MOTIVATIONAL COUNSELLOR
turns.text: Ask me why we're so successful.

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: Why are we so successful?

turns.speaker: MOTIVATIONAL COUNSELLOR
turns.text: I'm glad you asked me that question!

turns.speaker: MOTIVATIONAL COUNSELLOR
turns.text: What do you see out there?

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: ...Ants...

turns.speaker: MOTIVATIONAL COUNSELLOR
turns.text: Right!  Ants!  Millions of creatures, each with his assigned task, all pulling together!

turns.speaker: MOTIVATIONAL COUNSELLOR
turns.text: You see?  Being an ant is being able to say, "Hey -- <u>I'm</u> meaningless, <u>you're</u> meaningless."

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: But -- but I've always felt life was about finding meaning...and then sharing it with someone special, someone you love.

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: We declared war again?  Are you scared?

turns.speaker: WEAVER
turns.text: I'll be back.

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: Did you see that?  How he gave <u>you</u> the beers, not me?  I'm telling you, he's got something against workers.

turns.speaker: WEAVER
turns.text: I don't know what you're talking about, Z.

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: Come on -- everybody dumps on us workers.  You soldiers get all the glory.  Plus you get to go out into the world, meet interesting insects, and kill them.

turns.speaker: WEAVER
turns.text: Yeah, but you get to spend all day with those fabulous worker babes.

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: Weaver, they're career girls. They're obsessed with digging.  No, I'll probably never meet the girl for me.

turns.speaker: WEAVER
turns.text: Who said there was a girl for you? I was talking about a girl for me.  Don't you want your aphid beer?

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: I can't help it.  I have a thing about drinking from the anus of another creature.  Call me crazy.

turns.speaker: WEAVER
turns.text: Z, we've known each other a long time, right?

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: Of course.  You were born two seconds after me.

turns.speaker: WEAVER
turns.text: And all the time I've known you, you've been grumping and groaning. You should quit making waves.  Go with the flow.

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: Weaver, I'm an insect, not a liquid.

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: Hey, did you hear what he said?!

turns.speaker: WEAVER
turns.text: Poor guy's had one too many scouting missions.

turns.speaker: WEAVER
turns.text: Time to cut a rug, Z!

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: I'm not in the mood.  Even when they're off work, they follow orders.

turns.speaker: WEAVER
turns.text: Well, you just sit here and be a party-pooper.

turns.speaker: WEAVER
turns.text: Get real, Z!  She just dropped the scarf by accident!

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: Are you kidding?  There were sparks between us!  This scarf is a sign!

turns.speaker: WEAVER
turns.text: It's a sign that you're crazy!  Do you know what the penalty for impersonating a soldier is?

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: What's gonna go wrong?!  I take your place for the royal inspection.  Bala comes strolling down the line, she sees me -- <u>bingo</u>!  Love is rekindled, and she takes me up to the palace for a little...  tea and crumpets... and you take your place again, and go march around to your heart's content!

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: You have to help me.  Please, Weaver. Think of all the things I've done for you!

turns.speaker: WEAVER
turns.text: I can't think of any.

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: Well I'm gonna <u>start</u> doing things for you...

turns.speaker: WEAVER
turns.text: Will you introduce me to some worker girls?

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: You bet!  They'll really go for a sensitive guy like you!

turns.speaker: WEAVER
turns.text: Maybe I'll get lucky.  You know, Z, I wouldn't do this for anyone but you...

turns.speaker: WEAVER
turns.text: Wear this.

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: You're a real buddy.

turns.speaker: WEAVER
turns.text: Yeah, I know.

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: What do I do?

turns.speaker: WEAVER
turns.text: Don't tell anyone you're a worker. Follow that column over there.  And come right back after the inspection!

turns.speaker: Z
turns.text: Yeah, but I hate drowning more!  Now <u>dig</u>!

turns.speaker: WEAVER
turns.text: You heard the ant -- DIG!!!

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: I'm getting lonely.  Who are you talking to, anyway?

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: My mother.

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: That's sweet.  That's real sweet.

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: This the place?

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: Yeah.  How much?

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: You sure this is a good idea? DOBISCH Can't think of a better one.

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: I mean - barging in on your mother -- in the middle of the night?

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: Don't worry about the old lady. One squawk from her, and she's out of a job.

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: Not there.  Under the mat.

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: Under the mat?

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: So this is your mother's apartment?

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: That's right.  Maria Ouspenskaya. BLONDE  Hiya, Ouspenskaya.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh.  Hello there, Mrs. Dreyfuss.

turns.speaker: MRS. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Something the matter?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I seem to have dropped my key.  Oh -- here it is.

turns.speaker: MRS. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Such a racket I heard in your place -- maybe you had burglars.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, you don't have to worry about that -- nothing in there that anybody would want to steal...  Good night, Mrs. Dreyfuss.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Mrs. Dreyfuss, can I borrow some coffee -- and maybe an orange and a couple of eggs?

turns.speaker: MRS. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Eggs he asks me for. Oranges. What you need is a good horse-whipping.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Ma'am?

turns.speaker: MRS. DREYFUSS
turns.text: From me the doctor has no secrets. Poor girl -- how could you do a thing like that?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I didn't really do anything -- honest -- I mean, you take a girl out a couple of times a week -- just for laughs -- and right away she thinks you're serious -- marriage-wise.

turns.speaker: MRS. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Big shot! For you, I wouldn't lift a finger -- but for her, I'll fix a little something to eat.

turns.speaker: MRS. DREYFUSS
turns.text: You wouldn't have such a thing as a napkin, would you?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, I have some paper towels --

turns.speaker: MRS. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Beatnik! Go to my kitchen -- third drawer, under the good silver, there is napkins.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yes, Mrs. Dreyfuss. He starts out with a worried backward glance toward the two. Fran is just sitting there, the spoon in her hand, not touching the soup.

turns.speaker: MRS. DREYFUSS
turns.text: So what are you waiting for -- a singing commercial?

turns.speaker: MRS. DREYFUSS
turns.text: You must eat -- and you must get healthy -- and you must forget him. Such a fine boy he seemed when he first moved in here -- clean and cut -- a regular Ivy Leaguer. Turns out he is King Farouk. Mit the drinking -- mit the cha cha -- mit the no napkins. A girl like you, for the rest of your life you want to cry in your noodle soup? Who needs it! You listen to me, you find yourself a nice, substantial man -- a widower maybe -- and settle down -- instead of nashing all those sleeping pills -- for what, for whom? -- for some Good Time Charlie?  Sssh!

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: One napkin, coming up.  I wish we had some champagne to wrap it around.

turns.speaker: MRS. DREYFUSS
turns.text: What did I tell you?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Look, Mrs. Dreyfuss, you don't have to wait around. I'll wash the dishes and --

turns.speaker: MRS. DREYFUSS
turns.text: You wash 'em, you break 'em. I'll come back for them later.  If he makes trouble, give me a yell.

turns.speaker: MOFFETT
turns.text: All right -- I'll tell him.  Hey, Baxter -- that was Personnel. Mr. Sheldrake's secretary.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Sheldrake?

turns.speaker: MOFFETT
turns.text: She's been trying to reach you for the last twenty minutes. They want you up stairs.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: MOFFETT
turns.text: What gives, Baxter? You getting promoted or getting fired?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Care to make a small wager?

turns.speaker: MOFFETT
turns.text: I've been here twice as long as you have --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Shall we say -- a dollar?

turns.speaker: MOFFETT
turns.text: It's a bet.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Morning, Mr. Baxter.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Morning, Miss Kubelik.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What did you do to your hair?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: It was making me nervous, so I chopped it off.  Big mistake, huh?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I sort of like it.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Say, you got a lulu.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah.  I better not get too close.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Oh, I never catch colds.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Really?  I was looking at some figures from the Sickness and Accident Claims Division -- do you know that the average New Yorker between the ages of twenty and fifty has two and a half colds a year?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: That makes me feel just terrible.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Well, to make the figures come out even -- since I have no colds a year -- some poor slob must have five colds a year.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: That's me.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: You should have stayed in bed this morning.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I should have stayed in bed last night.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Twenty-seven.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You may not realize it, Miss Kubelik, but I'm in the top ten -- efficiency-wise and this may be the day -- promotion-wise.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: You're beginning to sound like Mr. Kirkeby already.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Why not? Now that they're kicking me upstairs --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Couldn't happen to a nicer guy.  You know, you're the only one around here who ever takes his hat off in the elevator.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: The characters you meet. Something happens to men in elevators. Must be the change of altitude -- the blood rushes to their head, or something -- boy, I could tell you stories --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I'd love to hear them. Maybe we could have lunch in the cafeteria sometime -- or some evening, after work --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I hope everything goes all right.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I hope so.  Wouldn't you know they'd call me on a day like this -- with my cold and everything --  How do I look?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Fine.  Wait.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh -- Miss Kubelik.  I've been waiting for you. FRAN You have?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I almost didn't recognize you -- this is the first time I've ever seen you in civilian clothes.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: How'd you make out on the twenty- seventh floor?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Great. Look -- have you seen The Music Man?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Would you like to?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I thought maybe we could have a bite to eat first -- and then --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: You mean tonight?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I'm sorry, but I can't tonight. I'm meeting somebody.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh.  You mean -- like a girl-friend?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: No. Like a man.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I wasn't trying to be personal -- it's just that the fellows in the office were -- whether you wondering about you ever --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Just tell 'em -- now and then.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: This date -- is it just a date -- or is it something serious?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: It used to be serious -- at least I was -- but he wasn't -- so the whole thing is more or less kaputt.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, in that case, couldn't you -- ?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I'm afraid not. I promised to have a drink with him -- he's been calling me all week --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, I understand.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, it was just an idea -- I hate to see a ticket go to waste --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: What time does the show go on?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Eight-thirty.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Well -- I could meet you at the theatre -- if that's all right.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: All right? That's wonderful! It's the Majestic -- 44th Street.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Meet you in the lobby. Okay?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You know, I felt so lousy this morning -- a hundred and one fever -- then my promotion came up -- now you and I -- eleventh row center -- and you said I should have stayed in bed.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: How is your cold?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What cold? And after the show, we could go out on the town --  I've been taking from Arthur Murray.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: So I see.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: They got a great little band at El Chico, in the Village -- it's practically around the corner from where you live.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Sounds good.  How do you know where I live?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, I even know who you live with -- your sister and brother-in- law -- I know when you were born -- and where -- I know all sorts of things about you.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: How come?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: A couple of months ago I looked up your card in the group insurance file.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I know your height, your weight and your Social Security number -- you had mumps, you had measles, and you had your appendix out.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Well, don't tell the fellows in the office about the appendix. They may get the wrong idea how you found out.  'Bye.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Eight-thirty!

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Marry Christmas.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Thank you.  I thought you were avoiding me.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What gave you that idea?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: In the last six weeks you've only been in my elevator once -- and then you didn't take your hat off.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, as a matter of fact, I was rather hurt when you stood me up that night --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I don't blame you. It was unforgivable.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I forgive you.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: You shouldn't.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You couldn't help yourself. I mean, when you're having a drink with one man, you can't just suddenly walk out on him because you have another date with another man. You did the only decent thing.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Don't be too sure. Just because I wear a uniform -- that doesn't make me a Girl Scout.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Miss Kubelik, one doesn't get to be a second administrative assistant around here unless he's a pretty good judge of character -- and as far as I'm concerned, you're tops. I mean, decency-wise -- and otherwise-wise.  Cheers.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Cheers.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: One more?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I shouldn't drink when I'm driving.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You're so right.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: By the power vested in me, I herewith declare this elevator out of order.  Shall we join the natives?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Why not?  They seem friendly enough.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Don't you believe it. Later on there will be human sacrifices -- white collar workers tossed into the computing machines, and punched full of those little square holes.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: How many of those drinks did you have?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Three.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I thought so.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You all right? What's the matter?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Nothing.  There are just too many people here.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Why don't we step into any office? There's something I want your advice about, anyway.  I have my own office now, naturally. And you may be interested to know I'm the second youngest executive in the company -- the only one younger is a grandson of the chairman of the board.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Guess I made a boo-boo, huh?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: No -- I like it.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Really? You mean you wouldn't be ashamed to be seen with somebody in a hat like this?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Of course not.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Maybe if I wore it a little more to the side --  is that better?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Much better.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, as long as you wouldn't be ashamed to be seen with me -- how about the three of us going out this evening -- you and me and the bowler -- stroll down Fifth Avenue -- sort of break it in --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: This is a bad day for me.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I understand. Christmas -- family and all that --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I'd better get back to my elevator. I don't want to be fired.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, you don't have to worry about that. I have quite a bit of influence in Personnel. You know Mr. Sheldrake?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: He and I are like this.  Sent me a Christmas card. See?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I thought maybe I could put in a word for you with Mr. Sheldrake -- get you a little promotion -- how would you like to be an elevator starter?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I'm afraid there are too many other girls around here with seniority over me.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: No problem. Why don't we discuss it sometime over the holidays -- I could call you and pick you up and we'll have the big unveiling --  -- you sure this is the right way to wear it?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I think so.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You don't think it's tilted a little too much --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Here.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: After all, this is a conservative firm -- I don't want people to think I'm an entertainer --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: The mirror -- it's broken.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I know. I like it this way -- makes me look the way I feel.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Your phone.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh.  Yes?  Just a minute.  If you don't mind -- this is sort of personal

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: All right. Have a nice Christmas.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Don't you remember? We were at the office party together --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Oh, yes -- office party -- Miss Olsen --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: That's right.  I told you we had a fight -- that's what it was about -- Miss Olsen -- you know that other girl you saw --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I don't understand --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: It's not important, Fran -- the main thing is that I got here in time -- and you're going to be all right --  -- isn't she, Doc?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I'm so tired -- DR. DREYFUSS Here -- drink this.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I'm sorry, Mr. Baxter.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Miss Kubelik --  -- you shouldn't be out of bed.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I didn't know -- I had no idea this was your apartment --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Let me help you.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I'm so ashamed. Why didn't you just let me die?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What kind of talk is that?  So you got a little over- emotional -- but you're fine now.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: My head -- it feels like a big wad of chewing gum. What time is it?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Two o'clock.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Where's my dress? I have to go home.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You're in no condition to go anywhere -- except back to bed.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: You don't want me here --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Sure I do. It's always nice to have company for Christmas.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Miss Kubelik, I'm stronger than you are --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I just want to go brush my teeth --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh -- of course. I think there's a new toothbrush somewhere.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Here. How about some breakfast?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: No -- I don't want anything.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I'll fix you some coffee.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Who are you calling, Miss Kubelik?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: My sister -- she'll want to know what happened to me.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Wait a minute -- let's talk this over first.  Just what are you going to tell her?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Well, I haven't figured it out, exactly.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You better figure it out -- exactly. Suppose she asks you why you didn't come home last night?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I'll tell her I spent the night with a friend.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Someone from the office.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: And where are you now?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: In his apartment.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: His apartment?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I mean -- her apartment.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What's your friend's name?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Baxter.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What's her first name?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Miss.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: When are you coming home?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: As soon as I can walk.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Something wrong with your legs?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: No -- it's my stomach.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Your stomach?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: They had to pump it out.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Miss Kubelik, I don't think you ought to call anybody -- not till that chewing gum is out of your head.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: But they'll be worried about me -- my brother-in-law may be calling the police --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: That's why we have to be careful -- we don't want to involve anybody -- after all, Mr. Sheldrake is a married man --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Thanks for reminding me.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I didn't mean it that way -- I was just talking to him on the phone -- he's very concerned about you.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: He doesn't give a damn about me.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, you're wrong. He told me --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: He's a liar. But that's not the worst part of it -- the worst part is -- I still love him.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: She doesn't seem to like you very much.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, I don't mind. As a matter of fact, I'm sort of flattered -- that anybody should think a girl like you -- would do a thing like this -- over a guy like me.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Oh. Did you find something here -- an envelope -- ?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yes, I've got it.  Don't you think we'd better destroy it? So it won't fall into the wrong hands -- ?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Open it.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: There's nothing here but a hundred dollar bill.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: That's right. Will you see that Mr. Sheldrake gets it?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You want me to move the television set in here?  You play gin rummy?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I'm not very good at it.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I am. Let me get the cards.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: You don't have to entertain me.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I think I'm going to give it all up.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Give what up?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Why do people have to love people, anyway?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah -- I know what you mean.  Queen.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I don't want it.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Pick a card.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: What do you call it when somebody keeps getting smashed up in automobile accidents?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: A bad insurance risk?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: That's me with men. I've been jinxed from the word go -- first time I was ever kissed was in a cemetery.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: A cemetery?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I was fifteen -- we used to go there to smoke. His name was George -- he threw me over for a drum majorette.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Gin.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I just have this talent for falling in love with the wrong guy in the wrong place at the wrong time. BUD  How many guys were there?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Three. The last one was manager of a finance company, back home in Pittsburgh -- they found a little shortage in his accounts, but he asked me to wait for him -- he'll be out in 1965.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Cut.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: So I came to New York and moved in with my sister and her husband -- he drives a cab. They sent me to secretarial school, and I applied for a job with Consolidated - but I flunked the typing test --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Too slow?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Oh. I can type up a storm, but I can't spell. So they gave me a pair of white gloves and stuck me in an elevator -- that's how I met Jeff --  Oh, God, I'm so fouled up. What am I going to do now?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You better win a hand -- you're on a blitz.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Was he really upset when you told him?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Mr. Sheldrake? Oh, yes. Very.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Maybe he does love me -- only he doesn't have the nerve to tell his wife.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I'm sure that's the explanation.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: You really think so?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: No doubt about it.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Can I have that pad and the pencil?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I'm going to write a letter to Mrs. Sheldrake.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You are?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: As one woman to another -- I'm sure she'll understand --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Miss Kubelik, I don't think that's such a good idea.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, for one thing, you can't spell. And secondly -- if you did something like that -- you'd hate yourself.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I don't like myself very much anyway.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Pick up your cards and let's go.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Do I have to?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You bet. I got a terrific hand.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You sure you want to throw that card?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Gin.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Who was that?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Just somebody delivering a bottle of champagne. Like some?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Would you mind opening the window?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Now don't go getting any ideas, Miss Kubelik.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I just want some fresh air.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: It's only one story down -- the best you can do is break a leg.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: So they'll shoot me -- like a horse.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Please, Miss Kubelik, you got to promise me you won't do anything foolish.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Who'd care?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I would.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Why can't I ever fall in love with somebody nice like you?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah. Well -- that's the way it crumbles, cookie-wise. Go to sleep.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: There's a call for you --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: For me?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: -- Mr. Sheldrake.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I don't want to talk to him.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I think you should. I have to run down to the grocery anyway -- all that's left around here is one frozen pizza --  I'll be right back -- okay?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Are you all right?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Sure.  What's that funny smell?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Gas.  Didn't you turn it on?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Yes. I was boiling some water to get the coffee stains out of my dress.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You turned it on -- but you didn't light it.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Are you supposed to?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: In this house, you're supposed to.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What are you doing with that?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I was washing my stockings, so I decided I might as well do your socks.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: It's very curious -- I could only find three and a half pair.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, things are a little disorganized around here.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Tennis racquet? Oh, I remember -- I was cooking myself an Italian dinner.  I used it to strain the spaghetti. FRAN  Why not?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: As a matter of fact, I'm a pretty good cook -- but I'm a lousy housekeeper.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Yes, you are,  When I was straightening up the couch, you know what I found? Six hairpins, a lipstick, a pair of false eyelashes, and a swizzle stick from the Stork Club.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: It's just that I'm the kind of guy who can't say no -- I don't mean to girls -- I mean --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: You mean to someone like Mr. Sheldrake.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I guess so.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I know so. He's a taker.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: A what?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Some people take, some people get took -- and they know they're getting took -- and there's nothing they can do about it.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I wouldn't say that --  What would you like to have for diner? There's onion soup and canned asparagus --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I really ought to be getting home. My family will be flipping by now.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You can't leave yet. The doctor says it takes forty-eight hours to get the stuff out of your system.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I wonder how long it takes to get someone you're stuck on out of your system? If they'd only invent some kind of a pump for that --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I know how you feel, Miss Kubelik. You think it's the end of the world -- but it's not, really. I went through exactly the same thing myself.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: You did?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, maybe not exactly -- I tried to do it with a gun.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Over a girl?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Worse than that -- she was the wife of my best friend -- and I was mad for her. But I knew it was hopeless -- so I decided to end it all. I went to a pawnshop and bought a forty-five automatic and drove up to Eden Park -- do you know Cincinnati?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: No, I don't.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Anyway, I parked the car and loaded the gun -- well, you read in the papers all the time that people shoot themselves, but believe me, it's not that easy -- I mean, how do you do it? -- here, or here, or here --  -- you know where I finally shot myself?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Here.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: In the knee?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Uh-huh. While I was sitting there, trying to make my mind up, a cop stuck his head in the car, because I was illegally parked -- so I started to hide the gun under the seat and it went off -- pow!

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: That's terrible.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah. Took me a year before I could bend my knee -- but I got over the girl in three weeks. She still lives in Cincinnati, has four kids, gained twenty pounds -- she sends me a fruit cake every Christmas.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Are you just making that up to make me feel better?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Of course not. Here's the fruit cake.  And you want to see my knee?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: No, thanks. The fellows in the office may get the wrong idea how I found out.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: So let 'em. Look, I'm going to cook dinner for us. We'll have the fruit cake for dessert. You just sit there and rest. You've done enough for one day.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Yes, nurse.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Are we dressing for dinner?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: No -- just come as you are.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Say, you're pretty good with that racquet.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You ought to see my backhand.  And wait till I serve the meatballs.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Shall I light the candles?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: It's a must -- gracious-living-wise.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I see you bought some napkins.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Might as well go all the way.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You know, I used to live like Robinson Crusoe -- shipwrecked among eight million people. Then one day I saw a footprint in the sand -- and there you were --  It's a wonderful thing -- dinner for two.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: You usually eat alone?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, no. Sometimes I have dinner with Ed Sullivan, sometimes with Dinah Shore or Perry Como -- the other night I had dinner with Mae West -- of course, she was much younger then.  Cheers.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Cheers.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You know what we're going to do after dinner?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: The dishes?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I mean, after that?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You don't have to if you don't want to --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I don't?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: We're going to finish that gin game.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: So I want you to keep a clear head.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, Miss Kubelik. How do you feel?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Fine. How's your eye?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: How's everything at the apartment?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Nothing's changed. You know, we never finished that gin game --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I know.  I suppose you heard about Mr. Sheldrake --?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You mean, leaving his wife? Yeah. I'm very happy for you.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I never thought he'd do it.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I told you all along. You see, you were wrong about Mr. Sheldrake.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I guess so.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: For that matter, you were wrong about me, too. What you said about those who take and those who get took? Well, Mr. Sheldrake wasn't using me -- I was using him. See?  Last month I was at desk 861 on the nineteenth floor -- now I'm on the twenty-seventh floor, paneled office, three windows -- so it all worked out fine -- we're both getting what we want.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Yes.  You walking to the subway?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: No, thank you.  I -- well, to tell you the truth --  -- I have this heavy date for tonight --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Aren't you meeting Mr. Sheldrake?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: No. You know how people talk. So I decided it would be better if we didn't see each other till everything is settled, divorce-wise.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: That's very wise.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Good night, Mr. Baxter.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Good night, Miss Kubelik.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Are you all right?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I'm fine.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Are you sure? How's your knee?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I'm fine all over.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Mind if I come in?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Of course not.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Where are you going? BUD Who knows? Another neighborhood -- another town -- another job -- I'm on my own.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: That's funny -- so am I.  What did you do with the cards?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: In there.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What about Mr. Sheldrake?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I'm going to send him a fruit cake every Christmas.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I love you, Miss Kubelik.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Seven --  -- queen.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Did you hear what I said, Miss Kubelik? I absolutely adore you.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Shut up and deal!

turns.speaker: MRS. LIEBERMAN
turns.text: Good evening, Mr. Baxter.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Good evening, Mrs. Lieberman.

turns.speaker: MRS. LIEBERMAN
turns.text: Some weather we're having.  Must be from all the meshugass at Cape Canaveral.  You locked out of your apartment?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: No, no.  Just waiting for a friend. Good night, Mrs. Lieberman.

turns.speaker: MRS. LIEBERMAN
turns.text: Good night, Mr. Baxter.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh -- Mrs. Lieberman.

turns.speaker: MRS. LIEBERMAN
turns.text: So who did you think it was -- Kris Kringle? What was going on here last night?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Last night?

turns.speaker: MRS. LIEBERMAN
turns.text: All that marching -- tramp, tramp, tramp -- you were having army maneuvers maybe?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I'm sorry, Mrs. Lieberman -- and I'll never invite those people again.

turns.speaker: MRS. LIEBERMAN
turns.text: What you get from renting to bachelors. All night I didn't sleep ten minutes -- and I'm sure you woke up Dr. Dreyfuss.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Don't worry about Dr. Dreyfuss -- I happen to know he was out on a case.

turns.speaker: MRS. LIEBERMAN
turns.text: I'm warning you, Mr. Baxter -- this is a respectable house, not a honky-tonky.  Come on, Oscar.

turns.speaker: MRS. LIEBERMAN
turns.text: Oh, Mr. Baxter -- I'm glad you're here -- I was just going to get the passkey.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: MRS. LIEBERMAN
turns.text: I thought I smelled gas coming from your apartment.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Gas?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Baxter?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I was sort of wondering what you looked like. Sit down.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yes, Mr. Sheldrake.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Been hearing some very nice things about you -- here's a report from Mr. Dobisch -- loyal, cooperative, resourceful --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Mr. Dobisch said that?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: And Mr. Kirkeby tells me that several nights a week you work late at the office -- without overtime.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, you know how it is -- things pile up.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Mr. Vanderhof, in Public Relations, and Mr. Eichelberger, in Mortgage and Loan -- they'd both like to have you transferred to their departments.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: That's very flattering.
